titlestmt.sponsor: This collection-level EAD record is a product of the Philadelphia Area Consortium of Special Collections Libraries (PACSCL) Consortial Survey Initiative, which was funded by the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: Machine-readable finding aid generated in EAD from data in the PACSCL Consortial Survey Database on 12/21/2012. Modified by Dot Porter in 2017.

bioghist.p: Jane M. Rosenthal (1925-2004) was a linguist and teacher. She received her bachelor's degree in journalism from Indiana University, where she also met her husband, Robert Rosenthal. After college, she worked as a reporter for the daily newspaper in Bedford, Indiana. After their marriage, the couple moved to Chicago, where Robert Rosenthal attended the Graduate Library School at the University of Chicago. He later became the head of the University's manuscript and archives collections. Jane Rosenthal taught English and citizenship to immigrant adults for several years, and then began graduate work in linguistics at the University of Chicago, earning her master's degree in 1971. Her specialization was the Aztec language. She then taught English language and linguistics at Chicago State University, Roosevelt University, and the National College of Education, where she was Coordinator of the Language Institute. While she taught, she continued her research in Nahuatl and Uto-Aztecan languages and Mexican history and culture, and pursued additional graduate coursework at the University of Chicago.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of the professional papers of Jane M. Rosenthal. Materials include: notes and drafts of Rosenthal's articles; copies of articles and manuscripts by others; conference and lecture handouts and notes; clippings; correspondence, much of it related to conferences; notebooks and index cards containing lexicons and glossaries; transcriptions and copies of classical texts in Spanish; and photographs and negatives.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
